poem:
"Upon Moulsham Street"

within the heartbeat of
a Chelmsford high street
each thrum a barber's snip,
a Chinese noodle slurped.

Kebab shops and greasy spoons,
culinary opulence
blooming in the most
restrained confines.

In this mosaic -
a star gleams,
the pie and mash shop.
A theme of nostalgia,
wrapped in dough,
bathed in fragments of
East End desire,
Moulsham Street pulses,
deliciously oscillating
between then and now.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘There’s a lot of nostalgia’: how cockney cuisine emigrated from the East End to Essex Moulsham Street in Chelmsford is a typical English high street, with barbers, salons, pubs and no shortage of culinary options: a Chinese, Indian, chippy and Italian, kebab shops and greasy spoons. But there’s one spot you wouldn’t find in most of the country – the pie and mash shop. F Cooke has all the trappings of a traditional pie and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
